text: we're here in greeley colorado with ken
buck the Republican nominee for the u.s.
senate thanks for being with us thank
you the central charge the democrats are
making against you right now is that you
embrace the Tea Party to win the
Republican nomination but now you're
flip-flopping on some issues on things
like support for the 17th amendment on
whether you are in fact part of the Tea
Party or not to hide your views in the
general election what do you say about
that nonsense I talked about the 17th
amendment the next morning I called the
gentleman said I don't think we should
repeal the 17th amendment 15 times on
the record during the 18 months that I
was running for the primary I talked
about the fact that I was opposed to
repealing the 17th amendment they are
creating something to make sure that
they do not have to deal with the issues
that the people of Colorado want to hear
about and those issues are jobs and the
economy and spending and they continue
to try to play in another sandbox and
eventually they're going to have to play
in that sandbox but what about the
broader issue aside from the 17th
amendment the idea that you're a tea
party exponent but you don't want to
admit that in the general recs no I'm
admitting I'm happy to admit it you know
the Tea Party gave me a lot of support
as did the 912 groups and the liberty
groups and other groups we really had a
grassroots campaign it's been on all of
our literature it's been all our signs
and I continue to talk about how ken
buck is the grassroots candidate not the
DC establishment candidate and Michael
Bennett fits into that DC establishment
framework very well and we will continue
to run as the grassroots
anti-establishment canopy many
Republicans are opposed and have pushed
for repeal the president's health care
law and some have said it's
unconstitutional the mandate that people
buy coverage do you have any doubts
about the constitutionality of the
Social Security program I have doubts
it'll be interesting to see what the US
Supreme Court ultimately does with it
it's hard to predict that but I have
some doubts with the individual mandate
I think it's a bad policy to force
people to buy health insurance and but
you also have doubts about the
constitutionality of Social Security no
i do not know and I've never said that
and I
I hope people look at the entire answer
to the question i don't have doubts
about social security to me it is clear
that the social security program is
constitutional whether it is being run
mandates participation it mandates
participation so what's the difference
well I think that it mandates
participation if you work it doesn't
mandate participation for just living in
this country and the health care program
does let's talk about your proposal
going forward to help deal with debt and
deficits on Social Security you've said
that you're in favor of raising the
retirement age and looking at private
accounts is that right no it's not right
what I've said is that we should look at
workers in three groups the first group
are folks that are in retirement right
now or close to retirement and I think
that we have made a sacred promise to
them they have paid in they have an
expectation and they have relied on on
that expectation in forming their
retirement plan and we should not touch
where those folks aren't right now
there's a group of workers in the middle
who I believe we need to look at things
like indexing the retirement age to life
expectancy we need to look at so that
would mean raising the retirement age
that's that's correct that's correct we
need to look at but not for everybody i
wanna make sure that that's that's clear
we need to look at means testing for
that group and then for the youngest
workers entering the workforce or just
having entered the workforce i think we
need to look at something that's going
to sustain Social Security and make sure
that they have a program that's that's
available to the private accounts what I
would do is I called social security
plus we have a Social Security system in
place they are part of that Social
Security system they are given a tax
incentive to set up a 401k type plan and
a private account that they would be
able to invest in certain government
approved programs they're not using the
payroll tax that not using the payroll
tax and so that would be the plus end of
it so there's still a safety net but
there is an incentive for folks to plan
for their retirement at an early age the
paul ryan republican ranking Republican
on the Budget Committee in the house is
proposed as part of his plan to bring
down debts debt and deficits over the
long term
a plan to turn Medicare into a voucher
system you agree with Paul Ryan on that
I don't I I haven't what I know is we've
made promises to folks in Medicare we
need to cut spending on a lot of
government programs to make sure that we
can keep those promises I haven't
decided whether some form of vouchers
works or not my reactant my reaction is
it probably won't and it probably won't
be accepted by the American public and
so we've got to find some other
alternatives but you're not ruling out
foul chures it sounds like your concern
is partly about the political
practicality not necessarily in
principle well I want to make sure that
seniors have a a medical care system in
place and and I'm not convinced at this
point that vouchers will replace
Medicare on a one-to-one basis I think
will be something less and I think we've
got to be careful with that but you take
a look at it what I can look at vouchers
I'm sure I'll look at everything but but
like i said i don't think that it is
something that is going to replace what
we have right now and that's the kief
kief or me the bush tax cuts expire at
the end of the year the president says
he wants to extend the tax cuts for
ninety-eight percent of the american
people who make under $250,000 and
family income but not for the people who
make more than that because we can't
afford it that's the only way to bring
the deficit down is to have some more
revenue and that's a place to look yeah
wrong with that what's wrong with it is
the president hasn't cared about the
deficit up to this point and and nor
have the members like Michael Bennet who
have supported president's proposals
like the the bailouts of the auto
companies and the banks the stimulus
plan other plans so I think that he is
once again playing a class warfare game
that is I think unfortunate that he's
playing at this point in time with an
election pending the folks that make
more than 250,000 are often the the
employers of in small businesses and we
need to make sure that those folks have
certainty that they are not getting a
tax increase because that's really what
are those people talk about extending
the Bush tax cuts it is a tax increase
for those that are going to have
have to pay more the Obama
administration as you know has a
commission looking into how to bring
down deficits and also how to reform the
tax system one of the options that
they're considering is moving from
income based taxes to consumption taxes
sales tax VAT whatever you you think
that's good idea to move toward
consumption taxes I think the VAT is a
bad idea in some ways a consumption tax
and national sales tax makes some sense
but I would be very concerned that the
Fair Tax well I am NOT a fair tax
proponent I think we need to simplify
the income tax code as the way to go and
not adopt a fair tax but I think that if
we move towards a fair tax if we move
towards the national sales tax we have
to make sure that we do away with the
income tax that we don't have just more
taxes in place in two different ways but
if you can if you could do away with the
income tax would it be better for the
economy and for the American people to
go to a sales tax there would be some
benefits to one of the benefits is our
competition in the international trade
the corporate income tax in particular
is a tax that puts American corporations
at a disadvantage I think we lose jobs
to overseas when we do that so there are
some advantages to a national sales tax
I think it is a very complicated issue
and how to transition from an income tax
to a sales tax I think the better answer
is for us to stay with an income tax and
simplified but it sounds like again your
concern is more practicality that that
in principle as a policy you think it
would be better no I've never said I
think would be better i think it would
be better to simplify the tax code um
you've said you want to repeal the
health care bill that the obama
administration pushed me would you also
repeal the financial regulation bill
that recently passed I i wouldn't repeal
the financial regulation bill wholesale
I think there are parts of it that makes
sense the the problem I had with the the
health care bill is twofold one I think
it was passed in a way that didn't give
Americans the confidence that Congress
was really acting in their best
interests and secondly I think it put a
lot of regulations and
they manipulated the market by having a
centralized healthcare system so I I
think we should repair it viola health
care bill I think we should start again
and I don't mean to say that we should
ignore the problem we should really
start and we should really address the
problems and we should have an open
debate and we should encourage both
sides of the aisle in the debate
something that I didn't see last oh
what's wrong with the financial
regulation bill what's wrong with it it
doesn't address the key issues of Fannie
Mae and Freddie Mac it doesn't it
creates a new agency that is in it as
far as I see it right now doesn't have
it's not an argument for passing
legislation on fannie mae and freddie
mac not repealing the stuff that got
passed when i said i wouldn't be in
favor of repealing the financial reform
act but i would be favor of amending it
and those were some of the amendments
that i would i would look in um you've
got problems obviously with the way the
president use government to intervene in
the economy and spending putting money
into general motors do you have the same
problem with the way the Federal Reserve
inserted itself into trying to lift the
economy and do you have problems with
how Ben Bernanke's conducted himself as
the Fed chair I think that it is
important to audit the Fed and to be
able to answer those questions i'm not
going to draw the conclusions to the
audit until we've had an audit and we've
been able to look at where did the money
go and tarp and and what other moves did
the Fed make in in late two thousand
eight and 2009 any concern as some
defenders of the Fed have said that
audits would ero the independence
traditional independence of the fact I
don't think that's true I think
transparency is an important concept in
American politics and i'm in favor of it
and i think that we have transparency to
an extent with the CIA we have
transparency to an extent with the
military we should have more
transparency with the fed on Bernanke
himself though should he be replaced i
think there are better qualified people
I'm not going to name any right now but
I think that time will tell whether he
has really moved this economy in the
right direction you'd like to see
somebody else in that job trade is an
issue that there's a lot of concern
about in the grassroots especially with
unemployment so high do you think NAFTA
was a mistake and should the United
States pull out of NAFTA no I don't
think napped it was a mistake why not
well
I think I am a free-trade person I think
that we need to have as open markets as
we can do other countries allow us the
same access that we allow them in my
opinion though but we have to work with
other countries to achieve free trade
and not strike down free trade
agreements talking to a Republican
Senate candidate another state also
embraced by some of the tea parties who
complained about how business has
approached the immigration issue I know
there's been controversy about whether
or not you do or don't support the
arizona immigration law but his
complaint was that business is using
illegal immigration to drive down wages
and hurt the American worker does that
bother you as well I I don't see it
sounds your question sounds like there's
some kind of grand conspiracy among
business to do that I think that is the
net effect of illegal immigration I
don't think that they're a group of
business people sitting around and
making that calculation but do you think
that immigration is good for the US
economy are not good for us okay the
immigration is essential for the US
economy illegal immigration is wrong um
two more issues or one more issue before
I let you go energy you're opposed to
the cap-and-trade plan that the
president has pushed in Colorado they've
approached the issue with renewable
portfolio standards and when those
standards were passed utilities exceeded
the requirements so that they've been
tightened a couple of times doesn't that
show that if you send signals to the
market about things that you want to
encourage and discourage the business
will adapt and it won't hurt the economy
yeah I don't know that we can draw the
conclusion at this point that it hasn't
hurt the economy I think that in in the
long run manipulating the market as they
have done is going to increase energy
costs and heard Colorado's to come so
you think what Colorado has done on
portfolio standards with utilities has
hurt the economy will hurt the economy I
think it will hurt the economy
ultimately I think that we need to have
a free market approach towards energy
and I think that we need to stop picking
winners and losers in that marketplace
and I think that setting environmental
standards is one thing and having
different energy sources achieve those
standards is great when you start
picking them in demanding that at least
ten percent or twenty percent or
twenty-five percent of
energy comes through renewable sources I
think that's wrong does that mean you
don't want government to do anything
about the issue of climate change know
of one I want to know what the science
is on climate change in my opinion don't
believe it I believe I don't believe
that the science is settled on a
man-made climate change different than
climate change on man-made climate
change and so while I live in Colorado
well you see where I live I love the
environment and I want to make sure we
do everything we can to protect the
environment I don't want government to
put artificial standards on on us that
doesn't mean that I'm not
environmentalist because I am I believe
strongly in conservation and in the
environment the president says green
jobs are one of the keys to our economic
future that baloney I don't think it's
baloney I think that they are an
important part of our future if they are
economically viable I think the key is
we've got abundant fossil fuel resources
in America we should stop the
importation of fossil fuels particularly
oil for a lot of reasons but the the
green economy certainly has a role in
the future of this country ken buck
thanks for being with us thank you
